hints_html:
You certainly CANNOT use the power rule (it only works if the exponent is a number). So what else can you do?

Logarithms have awesome properties with respect to exponents.

For instance,

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \log(a^n) = n \log(a)\end{aligned}\]
hints_latex:
You certainly CANNOT use the power rule (it only works if the exponent
is a number). So what else can you do?
Logarithms have awesome properties with respect to exponents.
hints_raw:
You certainly CANNOT use the power rule (it only works if the exponent is a number). So what else can you do?

:<math>\displaystyle
\log(a^n) = n \log(a)
</math>
question: 1 (h)
sols_html:
To differentiate this, we should use logarithmic differentiation. First, we rewrite the function:

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \ln(f(x)) = \ln{((\tan{x})^{\cos{x}})} = \cos(x)\ln{(\tan{x})}\end{aligned}\]

And then use implicit differentiation

\[\begin{aligned} (\ln(f(x)))' &= (\cos(x)\ln{(\tan(x))})'\\ \frac{1}{f(x)}f'(x) &= \cos(x)(\ln{(\tan(x))})'-\sin(x)\ln{(\tan(x))}\\ &=\cos(x)\frac{\sec^2(x)}{\tan(x)}-\sin(x)\ln{(\tan(x))}\end{aligned}\]

(Remember that the derivative of \(\tan(x)\) is \(\sec^2(x)\)). Now, simply solve for \(f'(x)\) to obtain the answer:

\[\begin{aligned} f'(x) &= f(x)\left(\frac{\cos(x)\sec^2(x)}{\tan(x)}-\sin(x)\ln{(\tan(x))}\right)\\ &= (\tan(x))^{\cos(x)}\left(\frac{\sec(x)}{\tan(x)}-\sin(x)\ln{(\tan(x))}\right)\\ &= (\tan(x))^{\cos(x)}\left(\frac{1}{\sin(x)}-\sin(x)\ln{(\tan(x))}\right)\\ &= (\tan(x))^{\cos(x)}\left(\csc(x)-\sin(x)\ln{(\tan(x))}\right)\end{aligned}\]

(Note that \(\cos(x)\sec^2(x) = \sec(x)\).)
sols_latex:
To differentiate this, we should use logarithmic differentiation. First,
we rewrite the function:

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
\ln(f(x)) = \ln{((\tan{x})^{\cos{x}})} = \cos(x)\ln{(\tan{x})}
\end{align*} And
then use implicit differentiation

\begin{align*}
(\ln(f(x)))' &= (\cos(x)\ln{(\tan(x))})'\\
\frac{1}{f(x)}f'(x) &= \cos(x)(\ln{(\tan(x))})'-\sin(x)\ln{(\tan(x))}\\
&=\cos(x)\frac{\sec^2(x)}{\tan(x)}-\sin(x)\ln{(\tan(x))}
\end{align*} (Remember that the derivative of $\tan(x)$ is
$\sec^2(x)$). Now, simply solve for $f'(x)$ to obtain the answer:

\begin{align*}
f'(x) &= f(x)\left(\frac{\cos(x)\sec^2(x)}{\tan(x)}-\sin(x)\ln{(\tan(x))}\right)\\
&= (\tan(x))^{\cos(x)}\left(\frac{\sec(x)}{\tan(x)}-\sin(x)\ln{(\tan(x))}\right)\\
&= (\tan(x))^{\cos(x)}\left(\frac{1}{\sin(x)}-\sin(x)\ln{(\tan(x))}\right)\\
&= (\tan(x))^{\cos(x)}\left(\csc(x)-\sin(x)\ln{(\tan(x))}\right)
\end{align*} (Note that $\cos(x)\sec^2(x) = \sec(x)$.)
sols_raw:
To differentiate this, we should use logarithmic differentiation. First, we rewrite the function:
:<math>\displaystyle
\ln(f(x)) = \ln{((\tan{x})^{\cos{x}})} = \cos(x)\ln{(\tan{x})}
</math>
And then use implicit differentiation
:<math>\displaystyle
\begin{align}
(\ln(f(x)))' &= (\cos(x)\ln{(\tan(x))})'\\
\frac{1}{f(x)}f'(x) &= \cos(x)(\ln{(\tan(x))})'-\sin(x)\ln{(\tan(x))}\\
&=\cos(x)\frac{\sec^2(x)}{\tan(x)}-\sin(x)\ln{(\tan(x))}
\end{align}</math>
(Remember that the derivative of <math>\tan(x)</math> is <math>\sec^2(x)</math>). Now, simply solve for &fnof;'(''x'') to obtain the answer:
:<math>\begin{align}
f'(x) &= f(x)\left(\frac{\cos(x)\sec^2(x)}{\tan(x)}-\sin(x)\ln{(\tan(x))}\right)\\
&= (\tan(x))^{\cos(x)}\left(\frac{\sec(x)}{\tan(x)}-\sin(x)\ln{(\tan(x))}\right)\\
&= (\tan(x))^{\cos(x)}\left(\frac{1}{\sin(x)}-\sin(x)\ln{(\tan(x))}\right)\\
&= (\tan(x))^{\cos(x)}\left(\csc(x)-\sin(x)\ln{(\tan(x))}\right)\\
\end{align}</math>
(Note that <math>\cos(x)\sec^2(x) = \sec(x) </math>.)
